Award.AwardTitle: Programming languages mentoring workshop at POPL17

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: The Sixth Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop (PLMW) will take place on January 17 2017, as part of the flagship programming language conference, Principles of Programming Languages (POPL), which will be held in Paris, France. This grant will support approximately 8 students to attend the PLMW event plus the POPL conference. While there is other funding available (through ACM SIGPLAN PAC) for students who are presenting papers at POPL, this proposal is intended specifically to increase the numbers of students from underrepresented groups and gives priority to US citizens and permanent residents. The broader significance and importance of the grant relate to the need to broaden participation, provide opportunities for students to receive mentoring from leading members of the programming languages community, and build the next generation of researchers and knowledgeable practitioners in this important research arena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A specific objective of PLMW was to bring women, under-represented minorities, and students with disabilities to POPL. To this end, the team publicized the workshop broadly, posting announcements on major email lists, web forums, and social media, and also by sending emails to researchers, encouraging their students to apply. In the end, PLMW received 186 applications and selected 46 students for scholarships. The selection committee attempted to identify students who would benefit most from attending POPL and PLMW, including students early in their career, those with a demonstrated interest in programming language research, and members of under-represented groups.

 

12 of the selected students identified as women, 3 as belonging to an underrepresented minority, and 4 as having a disability. This is, in general, a significantly higher representation than in the field at large, and female attendees remarked on the positive impact it had for them.

 

NSF was not the only source of funding, and not all students who received scholarships are based at US institutions. However, 41% of the selected students are based at US institutions thanks to NSF's contributions. NSF specifically partially funded 17 of the selected students. Of those students, 8 identified as women, and 2 identified as belonging to an underrepresented minority. Thus NSF's contributions had a significant effect on the number of women attendees. We received 8 applications that were both eligible for NSF funding and identified as an underrepresented minority, but most of such applications were at too early stages in their career (e.g., freshman and sophomores) and would have not benefitted from PLMW. We hope that these students will apply again for support later in their career.

 

That said, the representation of women has improved this year over previous years. This seems to because the PI analyzed the process used previous years for unintended structural biases against women and underrepresented minorities. The criteria used to determine who to offer a scholarship to was revised based on this informal analysis, which seems to have been effective. However, the lack of applications from NSF-eligible students belonging to underrepresented minorities suggest that more work needs to be done in reaching out to students and inviting them to apply.

 

Key outcomes or Other achievements:

The project was successful in its main goals: bringing undergraduate and graduate students to PLMW and POPL; providing them with mentorship, career advice, and opportunities for networking; and targeting women, under-represented minorities, and students with disabilities.
